text: (OTOH I hope that the work I do for programmers might become part of the underlying infrastructure of tools for non-programmers.)

elements.text: (OTOH I hope that the work I do for programmers might become part of the underlying infrastructure of tools for non-programmers.)

text: .. and I'd like to take this opportunity to once more assert that I, for one, am pursuing the Future of *Programming*, for *non-Coders* :smile:

text: I think about it as: in a future with sufficiently good education and tools, everyone is a programmer.

text: 6) :+1::skin-tone-3:

<@UDPV407CZ> Yeah I love that example. I think exploring a new medium is the perfect place for accessibility—and one of the 3 big design values or principles for Dynamicland is something like, “a humane medium accessible to all.” It will be interesting to see where the researchers go with it next.

text: 6) But (ironic to the label used), more intuitive and "human" than what currently exists

elements.text: 6) But (ironic to the label used), more intuitive and "human" than what currently exists

text: a lot of people answered "utterly alien"  what constitutes an utterly alien platform to you?

elements.text: a lot of people answered "utterly alien"  what constitutes an utterly alien platform to you?

text: I think a lot of the goals people here want to achieve are achievable on existing infrastructure, even if the high level UX is radically different, but I could be wrong.  I know some people are advocating simpler, more understandable open systems that anyone can reason about, which might be utterly alien compared to what we have now, sadly

text: <@UBN9AFS0N> <@UE6EFEPTQ> <@UAVCC2X70> I'm not convinced '6)' is a new category. The less you rely on existing platforms the more you're forced to be vertically integrated and your own eco-system. So they seem implicit. Self hosting seems like an implementation detail? Again, it could apply to any of these options? What am I missing?

elements.text: I'm not convinced '6)' is a new category. The less you rely on existing platforms the more you're forced to be vertically integrated and your own eco-system. So they seem implicit. Self hosting seems like an implementation detail? Again, it could apply to any of these options? What am I missing?

text:
<@UAVCC2X70>:

> 6) But (ironic to the label used), more intuitive and "human" than what currently exists

You mean 'alien'? Yes, I meant the word purely in the sense of "people used to existing systems will have lots of unlearning to do". Implicitly it's only worth doing if the new thing is (lots) better for humans than the old thing.

Totally worth doing. Only a miniscule fraction of total computer users have been born so far, so it seems short-sighted to emphasize those of us who just happened upon the scene first.

elements.text: 6) But (ironic to the label used), more intuitive and "human" than what currently exists

You mean 'alien'? Yes, I meant the word purely in the sense of "people used to existing systems will have lots of unlearning to do". Implicitly it's only worth doing if the new thing is (lots) better for humans than the old thing.

Totally worth doing. Only a miniscule fraction of total computer users have been born so far, so it seems short-sighted to emphasize those of us who just happened upon the scene first.

text: Though I'm really oriented along a different axis.  It's not Programmers vs Non-programmers so much as... well it's not  Professionals vs Amateurs either, but that's getting closer.  I mean sometimes it's great to get an 80% solution quick.  Sometimes it's great to get a 99.9% solution through endless tweaking, blood, and tears.   So maybe there's another direction, call it up, that's neither quick nor twiddly.

elements.text: Though I'm really oriented along a different axis.  It's not Programmers vs Non-programmers so much as... well it's not  Professionals vs Amateurs either, but that's getting closer. text: Now this is a good poll!  Definitely in the (5) camp.

elements.text: Now this is a good poll!  Definitely in the (5) camp.

text:
<@UCUSW7WVD> - I meant to say (5), although what I have in mind is the same thing that Mariano posted as (6). I didn't notice that he created a new option.

I meant that it would be more alien in comparison to current systems, but much more human-friendly. In other words, the future of coding (as I see it) is much *less* alien to humans, than current systems are.

text: My future makes that line very blurry and way to cross. There's still a spectrum, but much less of a barrier. So, it's definitely for both
